Context:
The Computer Systems Technology online program is a three-year course offered by George Brown College. It consists of two optional specializations in the third year: Networking and Systems. Both specializations include core courses on infrastructure virtualization, cloud computing, network security, voice-over-IP (VoIP), wireless LANs, mail server administration, content management systems, database administration, and computer security. Students will gain hands-on experience using up-to-date networking, wireless, radio frequency, VoIP, and security lab equipment.

In the third year of the program, students will be involved in real-life projects or case studies. These may be completed independently, with industry partners, or with George Brown's Office of Research and Innovation. Students have recently helped develop IT solutions for various well-known companies in the Greater Toronto Area, including Bell Mobility, Rogers Communications, Cogeco Data Systems, and many others.

The program covers all courses of the official Cisco CCNA Routing & Switching curriculum and prepares students to write several other examinations leading to industry certifications, such as the Certified Wireless Network Administrator (CWNA) and Cisco Certified CyberOps Associate. Students starting in January (winter term) will be required to attend classes during the summer months (May to August).

This is an online-only program for domestic students. However, regular in-person delivery and international eligibility are available through the Computer Systems Technology (T147) program. The Networking specialization focuses on network security, VoIP, and wireless LANs, while the Systems specialization focuses on mail server administration, content management systems, database administration, and computer security.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Computer Systems Technology Program (Online) T187 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context:
Expected Attendance: The term "will be required to attend classes during the summer months (May to August)".

Technology Requirements: Students need a personal computer with at least 16 GB RAM, a minimum 256 GB SSD Hard Drive (500+ GB recommended), a quad-core i7 2.4GHz processor or better, a video card with a minimum of 2GB RAM and 4GB RAM recommended, and a webcam.

Career Opportunities: This program prepares graduates for jobs in technical support, web development, field technician (wireless/cellular service providers), training service provider, system and network administrator, cybersecurity analyst, and systems manager. Graduates may also find employment in companies providing computer support services to other businesses or organizations specializing in the sale and installation of computer systems and networks.

Transfer Pathways: Opportunities for transfer credits toward further study to attain a degree are available, with qualifying graduates able to enter Ontario college graduate certificate and university degree programs. Articulation agreements exist between George Brown College and various other post-secondary institutions like the University of Ontario Institute of Technology, McMaster University, and the Northern Alberta Institute of Technology.

Required Courses:
SEMESTER 1: COMP 1151 (IT Essentials), COMP 1236 (Fundamentals of Computing Logic), COMP 1234 (Introduction To Web Development), GSSC 1027 (Personal Finance), MATH 1162 (Mathematics for Computer Technology I), COMM 2000 (Communicating Across Contexts)

SEMESTER 2: COMP 1176 (Introduction to Networks), COMP 3044 (Linux Essentials), COMP 1250 (Introduction to Programming), COMP 3105 (Enterprise Desktop Operation Systems), MATH 1172 (Mathematics for Computer Technology II), GNED (General Education Elective)

SEMESTER 3: COMP 3136 (Network Infrastructure)

Context:
ITIL Foundation is a part of the following programs offered by the college:
- COMP 3108: Cloud Computing Infrastructure
- COMP 3099: Capstone Project
- COMP 3125: Cybersecurity Operations
- COMP 3121: System Data Collaboration

The graduates of this program will be able to:
- Identify, analyze, design, develop, implement, verify and document the requirements for a computing environment.
- Diagnose, troubleshoot, document and monitor technical problems using appropriate methodologies and tools.
- Analyze, design, implement and maintain secure computing environments.
- Communicate and collaborate with team members and stakeholders to ensure effective working relationship.
- Select and apply strategies for personal and professional development to enhance work performance.
- Apply project management principles and tools when responding to requirements and monitoring projects within a computing environment.
- Adhere to ethical, social media, legal, regulatory and economic requirements and/or principles in the development and management of the computing solutions and systems.
- Investigate emerging trends to respond to technical challenges.
- Analyze, plan, design, implement and administer computer systems and cloud solutions.
- Research, design, deploy, configure, troubleshoot, maintain, upgrade and decommission computing system infrastructures.
- Select and apply scripting tools and programming languages to automate routine tasks.
- Install, monitor, optimize and administer a database management system in response to specified requirements.
- Design, implement and administer technical support processes for computing system infrastructures that aligns with industry best practice.

The tuition for the first two semesters of this program is $4,079.00 for domestic students. This fee is subject to change for programs starting in Fall 2023 and at later dates.

This program is approved for OSAP funding, provided the applicant meets OSAP eligibility criteria.

Admission for this program is based on academic achievement.

Context:
The text provides information about the admission requirements and how to apply for the Computer Technology program at George Brown College. Applicants need an Ontario Secondary School Diploma or equivalent, with a grade 12 English (C or U) and either a grade 11 math (M or U) or grade 12 (C or U). Mature students (19 years of age or older without OSSD) may take the Admissions Assessment for English and math or consider upgrading to achieve the required credits. The college grants course exemptions based on previous college or university credits, which can be checked through the Transfer Guide.

Domestic students should apply through Ontario Colleges. Contact information for the School of Computer Technology includes a phone number (416-415-5000, ext. 4287), an email address (computertechnology@georgebrown.ca), and office hours from Monday to Friday, 9 a.m. to 4 p.m. The Computer Systems Technology program is offered at the Casa Loma Campus located at 146 Kendal Avenue in Toronto. Interested individuals can sign up for an information session or campus tour and explore related programs like Computer Programming and Analysis (T177) and Computer Systems Technician (T141).

Phone numbers and email addresses:
- School of Computer Technology: 416-415-5000, ext. 4287, computertechnology@georgebrown.ca
- George Olenewa (Program Co-ordinator): 416-415-5000, ext. 6809, jolenewa@georgebrown.ca

Campus location:
Computer Systems Technology program - Casa Loma Campus at 146 Kendal Avenue, Toronto

Programs offered:
- Computer Systems Technology (T147)
- Computer Programming and Analysis (T177)
- Computer Systems Technician (T141)
